review.title: Topic Grids for Homogeneous Data Visualization
review.abstract: We propose the topic grids to detect anomaly and analyze the behavior based on the access log content. Content-based behavioral risk is quantified in the high dimensional space where the topics are generated from the log. The topics are being projected homogeneously into a space that is perception- and interaction-friendly to the human experts.

sections.text: I. INTRODUCTIONIn order to make the data points in high-dimensional space H visible to humans, a method of word embedding (or dimension reduction) is used to map the data points into a lower dimensional space L. The method of word embedding attempts to maintain a relationship between the data points in H after they have been mapped to L. The output of the dimension reduction algorithm is a series of data points that are unevenly scattered across the visualization space. This helps to explain cluster behavior, including cluster and intra-cluster behavior between the data points. However, there are also some drawbacks: 1) The clusters confuse with others, some data points overlap with others. Overlapping makes the information less perceptible. 2) The data points are denser in some areas. The heterogeneity of the data points makes human interaction with the data points more difficult. To better use the visualization space, we suggest distributing the data points evenly over the visualization points.

sections.heading: IV. APPLICATION AND CONCLUSION
sections.text: We use the SD algorithm to analyze cybersecurity behavioral content. The goal of the system is to detect behavioral anomalies based on the access logs. A log entry usually has a timestamp, a unique identifier of a user, an action, and the content on which the action was performed. If punctuated correctly, the path, content, and / or any metadata related to that access can be considered a document designated as a content topic. We use the latent dirichlet allocation model [3] to decide the topics between all of these content documents within a reference period. In our system, 64 topics are generated in a word vector space of 19K + dimensions. Relevance between a content document and each topic is measured, and the anomaly or risk of access is quantified by comparing the topics involved in that access with the topics involved in the historical accesses of the same user.
